experience: You and Evan both know JD Lasica, John Furrier, and 79 others
Focused on the intersection of business and social purpose.

Consulting various companies on product launch and increasing profitability. Projects include:  •  A company with a proprietary projection technology... Made suggestions on refining technology, then determined best markets to approach and ultimately entered the digital gaming market, tracked down "decision-making"​ contacts in the industry and the assisted with patent process.  •  A brick and mortar clothing store with three locations but no online presence... built their website, started an online customer loyalty program, leveraged their social media channels for online sales and a growing mailing list.  •  Franchise monitoring software... In charge of the implementation of financial monitoring software, which tied in with franchisees' QuickBooks so franchisor could monitor correct payment of royalties and track the patterns of the most successful franchisees to then use in training of other franchisees to increase their profitability.  •  A service based website that relied on hourly charges... Created a product that utilized the experience of one individual into a digital product that could be systemized to service thousands, dramatically increasing the website's profitability.

Synovativ Technologies, Inc. merged with THINK360 in Austin, Texas to further develop the Day-to-day Screen Calendar technology. Improvements included the ability to update remotely through a mechanism that couldn't be blocked or filtered with typical e-mail filters and the ability to target content for the end-user without the use of cookies. This was patented on November 26, 2008 with myself as the lead inventor (see patent below).At this time the product was called Desktop Channel™ and a notable project was with Dell computer's Small and Medium Business division where small business owners would receive the application pre-installed and could then choose the business publication from magazine publishers from which they would like to receive content.

Recognizing the inherent limitations of paper in the publishing and advertising world, I started to develop a digital version of my day-to-day medical humor product. I wasn't the "coder"​ for the project, but the concept guy who would communicate with the technical staff and then sell it to customers. This product at the time was called AdDiem and then later Day-to-Day Screen Calendar, where a recipient could choose the content of greatest interest and get a daily dose of the content at the time they chose through a proprietary desktop application.Projects included the celebration of ESPN's 25th anniversary, an in-house project to train SBC (AT&T) customer service employees called FaciliTrainer and others.

While a pre-med student working at a local hospital, I developed a concept for a day-to-day medical humor publication. After being turned down by major publishers because of not being a known author, I developed, produced and distributed the product myself, and within two years I had the top sale-through publication in the industry. Soon after copy-cat products came to market, but mine has remained on the shelf for 24 years now.In addition to retail sales, I had a product that got the attention of physician's on a daily basis and sold custom versions to the advertising specialty industry, first for the pharmaceutical trade, then later other custom projects for large companies like Lowe's home improvement stores.I sold the publication rights to Andrews McMeel in 2003 and the product, and the genre of occupational humor, is still on the shelves and a strong seller today, more than two decades later.
Course work in marketing, pre-med and linguistics.

Recruit medical personnel (surgeons, dentists, nurses) to travel to China to provide needed medical services and to educate Chinese medical providers on their surgical procedures. Responsible for their travel to and within China and all professional and housing accommodations.

There was a time that I churned through college interns as a way to evaluate talent without much of an obligation, and there were some that didn't last even a week.  However with Nilay, I could tell very quickly that he was very sharp but also very teachable, which is an unusual and special combination.  Nilay quickly became an employee after his internship.In addition to his intelligence and raw talent, I entrusted him with some information and responsibilities that I didn't share with any other employees and he never let me down -- not once.For me Nilay is "the one who got away" and I would hire him back in a second, with absolute conficence that he could learn whatever he was asked.

summary: A product launch specialist with a knack for recognizing the untapped opportunities within a marketplace.With my experience of having created a new genre of product, which I carried out from concept to the shelf, and is still a top-selling product more than two decades later, I then took this same product concept, created another stand-alone marketing opportunity by digitizing and obtaining a methodology patent on it, and carried out large scale implementations with companies such as SBC (acquired by AT&T), ESPN and Dell computers.I have since consulted other companies with their product concepts to receive investment, determine viability, product placement, walk through the patent process, analyze potential markets, launch strategy, additional revenue opportunities, monetization models, etc.
